body_content.explanation: something that is always ready for use, especially if a regular one fails:
examples: Board games are a good standby to keep the children amused if the weather is bad.
There are standby generators but these usually only have to work for a few hours a year during power cuts.

body_content.explanation: When a person or a thing is on standby, they are or it is ready to be used if necessary:
examples: Hospitals are on standby ready to deal with casualties from the crash.

body_content.explanation: When an electrical device such as a television is on standby, the power is on but the device will not work until a switch, etc. is pressed. :
examples: Not leaving your TV on standby at night will save you money.

body_content.explanation: When someone is on standby, they are waiting for a seat that might become available just before a flight or performance:
examples: I was too late for my flight but I managed get on standby for a later one.

body_content.explanation: a cheaper ticket sold just before a flight or a performance if there is a seat available:
examples: Tickets start at about at about £7, with cheap standbys sometimes available to students on the evening of the performance.
About 850 standby tickets have been given to those hoping to take the place of no-shows.
